bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, December 17, 1942

div1.p: Truby writes about the progress with his publisher on his book manuscript and responds further to Hench's suggestion that he may encounter some harsh remarks from literary critics.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, December 17, 1942
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Dec. 17/42
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have delayed answering your
letter, which came on the 15th, with the
expectation that I would have some news
from Harpers. As I wrote you in my
last letter, I wrote Mr. MacGregor to advise
me re the illustrations they wanted to eliminate.
On Dec 3, his secretary wrote that he was
away for a week and would take up my
correspondence later. She also stated
that the mms. had arrived. I expect that
several people have to be consulted,
and that takes time. I should hear something
soon, I think. In fact I think I will
hold this until the Sat. a.m. mails are delivered
and then forward this so you will get it
on Monday with the last word from Harpers if any.

I was dreadfully sorry I could not be
at the Military Surgeons' Luncheon last Tuesday.
Kean & Russell are the two best friends
I had in the Corps. I also knew Admiral Stitt
too, and the selection of those three for the
honors meets my hearty approval. I wish
you could have known Kean in his younger
days. A truly wonderful fellow.

Re. my story I feel that I have a mass
AC
T
2
of information which should not be lost, but
I fully realize that my inexperience in
writing will be promptly recognized by
literary critics. My own estimate is that
the first half of the book will be interesting
but the last part is not so well done and
much of it probably should have been omitted.
However, I could not do that over without
a secretary. Too much work. I suppose
there will be many criticisms, too, of the
statements made, but I have done my very
best to stick to things which I believe
are true. How the Cubans will react
I do not know. On the whole they will
like the story but will find much to take
exception to about Finlay & Agramonte. On
those points I know that I am right. As
youAs I have written you many times,
you will uncover enough about Agramonte
in time to find that I am right about
him. Agramonte's letters to Mrs. Lazear, which
you told me about, are terrible. I was so glad
to find out why he was not at Lazear's funeral,
and why he did not see Lazear when sick.

So you see I fully understood your remarks
about criticisms I will get. I appreciate
your estimate of the story and when I am
too old & feble to answer the critics you
will have to come to my defence. I think
3
time will help to convince you that there
are not many errors in my statements.
I found it awfully hard to write about
myself, but I simply could not have
qualified as an author on the work done
by the Reed Board without showing my background.
I was really quite a live wire at the time I was
in Cuba; was into everything; knew what
was going on; and had friends. Fortunately,
my memory is good and has been kept active
in the Cuban experience by constant demands for
info. re that period. So it had to be done in
that way. Some will condemn me for that.
However, who cares, if I have added anything
to the historical data on that great work.

Thanks for the photos. The one of you and
Mrs Hench is excellent. It was also nice
to know about your kiddies and the expected
one. Mrs Truby & I have had four and
the youngest one (Jack) was 15 years younger
than the youngest of the 1st three. So if
you are having a thrill after 9 years,
imagine what a thrill we had -
Jack has surprised us at West Point by
bring no. 30 from the top in Math, in a plebe class of 1055.
He was not quite 18 when he entered there
last July. He is also on the A. squad in
swimming, something no plebe has ever
AC
T
4.
accomplished before. He is over 6 ft tall
and a fine physical specimen. I tell you
all this so you will be prepared for a
very fine specimen in your old age.
I hope you like a little kidding! I always
enjoy it and have been blessed with
a good sense of humor. It makes life
worth living.

Congratulations on your award by the
Heberden Society. That is a real honor.

If you ever come out here bring that
picture of the 2d Div. Hospital and we will
see if we cant orient things. I haven't
a copy of that photo. If we can locate
the tree by Lazear's house it would help.
If someone can pick out the N and South
line from the shadows it would help.
As I remember it, the picture was taken in
April at which time the noonday sun, in that latitude,
should be almost overhead I think. A real
navigator could probably locate the true N. from
something in the picture. It was probably taken
during the lunch hour as there is no sign of
flife as I remember the picture.

Sat morning - nothing from Harpers. Will
advise you promptly when I hear from
them. Merry Christmas to you & yours
